name: annal
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
[ usually plural ] historical records of the activities of a country, organization, group, etc.; history in general: The signing of the Treaty of Rome was the greatest event in the annals of European integration. The crime of genocide, as carried out in the twentieth century, was unknown to human annals even during the darkest ages. There's no precedent for this crash in the annals of commercial aviation.
[ usually plural ] a serious magazine or newspaper that is published regularly about a scientific subject: The new guidelines are published in today's Annals of Internal Medicine.
a record of the events of one year: The annal for 1086 in this version of the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle was written c. 1121.
a record of one event in a chronicle (= a written record of historical events): The final sentence of the annal on Cnut's marriage to Emma refers to Eadric of Mercia's execution.
More examplesFewer examplesNo one in the annals of the state had ever been successfully prosecuted under this law.In the annals of composition, these songs represent a new, truly American style.The syndrome has not yet earned official designation in the annals of psychiatry.Their work was made public earlier this year in the Annals of Human Genetics.The Chronicle annal for 1022 is thoroughly obscure.This event was recorded in three separate annals.
